prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information
Defences Raised as a Result of the Plaintiff's Inaction

para.paratext: In many cases, a defence of laches will be brought in conjunction with a claim of acquiescence. In De Bussche v. Alt,[1] the court noted that:

If a person having a right, and seeing another person about to commit, or in the course of committing an act infringing upon that right, stands by in such a manner as really to induce the person committing the act, and who might otherwise have abstained from it, to believe that he assents to its being committed, he cannot afterwards be heard to complain of the act. This … is the proper sense of the term “acquiescence,” and in that sense may be defined as quiescence under such circumstances as that assent may be reasonably inferred from it, and is no more than an instance of the law of estoppel by words or conduct.

As with the law regarding laches, there is no fixed set of criteria that must be fulfilled in order to bring the defence of acquiescence. However, the following factors will be taken into consideration:
a lengthy delay on the part of the plaintiff in commencing proceedings, leading the defendant to believe that the plaintiff has abandoned its entitlement to a claim;
settlement discussions if the plaintiff's conduct would lead the defendant to believe the plaintiff has abandoned its claim; and
prejudice to the defendant as a result of the plaintiff's failure to pursue legal proceedings.[2]

In Barrick Gold Corp. v. Goldcorp Inc.,[3] the plaintiff had an ownership interest in the Barrick Agreement and, as such, was entitled to a duty of confidence in its favour respecting disclosure of this Agreement. However, it waived any right it might otherwise have had to prevent disclosure of the Barrick Agreement by its acquiescence to such disclosure. The plaintiff received a copy of the December 18 New Gold Letter and had notice from that letter that New Gold was proposing to disclose the Barrick Agreement to at least one of the parties named in the earlier New Gold disclosure letters. Moreover, it is understood that the parties named in the earlier disclosure letters comprised only mining companies and trading companies. As Goldcorp was named in the December 8 New Gold Letter, it therefore knew, or should have known, that Goldcorp was a potential recipient of the Agreement. The plaintiff did not raise any issue concerning the disclosure to Goldcorp of the Barrick Agreement. Its only reaction, upon receiving this correspondence was to inquire about an entirely separate issue. The trial judge concluded that the plaintiff's acquiescence should be interpreted under the law of Ontario as an acknowledgment that such disclosure was permissible in the context of a prospective purchase of the 70% Interest or, alternatively, as a waiver of any claim it might otherwise have had.[4]
De Bussche v. Alt (1877), 8 Ch. D. 286 (C.A.), at p. 314.
